== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Childhood and career beginnings ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson was born on July 10, 1980, in Abilene, Texas.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She is the first child of Tina Ann Simpson (née Drew), a homemaker, and Joseph "Joe" Simpson, a psychologist and Baptist youth minister.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson's parents married in 1978; they divorced in 2013.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson has stated that she grew up in Dallas and Waco, but her parents now live in McGregor, Texas.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson has a younger sister, Ashlee.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: In her preteens she briefly attended Amelia Middle School while her father did outreach in Cincinnati, Ohio.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: After moving back to Texas 20 months later, she attended J. J. Pearce High School in Richardson during her teenage years, though she had to drop out in 1997 as her career began to take off; a year later she later earned her GED via distance learning through Texas Tech High School.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Being a daughter of a minister, Simpson was raised with a strong Christian faith.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She was given a purity ring by her father when she was twelve years old.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Jessica and her family moved frequently due to her father's job, though they remained in Texas for the most part, they did live in the Midwest for a few years.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Her father would often take in unwed mothers for periods of time to provide them shelter.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She began singing in the church choir as a child.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: When she was eleven, she realized she hoped to achieve success as a singer
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: while at a church retreat.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson auditioned for The Mickey Mouse Club at the age of twelve, auditioning with a performance of "Amazing Grace" and dancing to "Ice Ice Baby" (1990).
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She advanced through multiple rounds, eventually being a semi-finalist for the show alongside artists such as Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, and Justin Timberlake.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson claimed that she became nervous about her final audition after seeing Aguilera perform, and she ultimately was not selected for the show.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson resumed performing in her church choir, eventually being discovered by the head of a Christian music label.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: He initially asked her for an audition, and immediately signed her after she performed "I Will Always Love You" (1973) by Dolly Parton.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She began working on her debut album with Proclaim Records, and began touring to promote the project.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Jessica's father later claimed that she had to quit touring as the size of her breasts led to her being deemed too "sexual" for the genre.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Her debut album, Jessica, remained unreleased after Proclaim Records went bankrupt; despite this, her grandmother personally funded a limited pressing of the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Shortly after this, Simpson landed several auditions as Jessica was sent to numerous labels and producers.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: She ultimately caught the attention of Tommy Mottola, then-husband of Mariah Carey and the head of Columbia Records.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: He went on to sign her to the label, claiming "She had a great little look and a great attitude, a fresh new face, and something a bit different than Britney and all of them; she could actually sing."
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Simpson began working on her debut album in Orlando, Florida.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: Mottola hoped to market Simpson as a contrast to Spears and Aguilera, both of whom had launched successful careers focused on dancing and sexuality.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: While working on her musical debut, Simpson enlisted her father Joe as her manager; her mother became her stylist.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===

sentences: While at a Christmas party in 1998, Simpson met 98 Degrees singer Nick Lachey, and the two began dating; Lachey claimed that he left the party and proclaimed to his mother that he would marry Simpson some day.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1998: Childhood and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===
== Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson began working on her debut studio album in 1998.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Mottola wanted Simpson to embrace an "anti-sex appeal" image while promoting the record, as a contrast to highly successful artists Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: He believed the image would make Simpson more "relatable" to listeners, therefore aiding in sales.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson went on to announce her plans to remain abstinent until marriage as a result of Mottola's decision.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Her debut single, "I Wanna Love You Forever" (1999), was released on September 28.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The single became a success in numerous territories, most notably reaching number three on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The song earned a platinum certification from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for sales exceeding one million copies in the country.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The album had some success in other territories as well, most notably in several European countries.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson's debut studio album, Sweet Kisses (1999), was released on November 23.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The album sold 65,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number sixty-five on the Billboard 200 chart in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: To promote the record, "Where You Are" (2000) was released as the second single from the album; Simpson's boyfriend Nick Lachey was featured on the track.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: "I Think I'm in Love with You" (2000) served as the album's third and final single, and achieved success in territories such as the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: With the success of the album's third single, Sweet Kisses rose to a new peak of number twenty-five on the Billboard 200 in August 2000.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The album sold over two million copies in the United States, earning a double platinum certification from the RIAA.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson embarked on the Heat It Up Tour with her boyfriend's band, 98 Degrees, as their opening act to promote Sweet Kisses throughout 2000.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Work on her second album began in 2000, opting to record more "radio-friendly" and upbeat songs for the record.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: During the recording of the album, Simpson adopted a more mature public image, a decision made by both Simpson and her record label in hopes to achieve the success of artists such as Spears.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: While working on the record, Simpson ended her relationship with Lachey to focus on furthering her career; the two would later reconcile in September.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: In a July 2001 interview with Coventry Newspapers, Simpson explained "I recorded [Sweet Kisses] when I was seventeen years old and I'm twenty-one
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: [this month] so there is four years of growth involved."
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson released the record's title track, "Irresistible" (2001) as the lead single from the project in April.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The single received a generally mixed reaction from critics due to its sexual themes, though went on to become her second top twenty hit on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Simpson released her second studio album, Irresistible (2001) in May.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: The album sold 127,000 copies in the United States during its first week of release, debuting at number six on the Billboard 200 chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: Though the album's first week sales were nearly double that of her previous effort, Irresistible failed to match the success of her debut album; the record earned a gold certification from the RIAA for sales of 500,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: "A Little Bit" (2001), the album's second and final single, failed to achieve much success.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: To promote the record, Simpson embarked as a co-headliner on the Total Request Live Tour (2001) alongside artists such as Destiny's Child and Nelly.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===

sentences: She later left the tour to launch her own DreamChaser Tour (2001), for which Simpson added choreography and backup dancers to her performances; the tour was canceled following the September 11 attacks.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2001: Breakthrough with early musical releases ===
== Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson announced her engagement to Nick Lachey in February 2002, with the two holding their wedding ceremony on October 26 in Austin, Texas.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson began working on her third studio album in 2002.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The album's lead single, "Sweetest Sin" (2003), lyrically dealt with the topic of Simpson losing her virginity to Lachey.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The song failed to achieve commercial success.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson's father pitched an idea to MTV about a reality show starring the couple, resulting in the creation of Newlyweds: Nick and Jessica.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The series initially focused on the marriage between Michael Jackson and Lisa Marie Presley, though the two backed out, thus allowing Simpson and Lachey to replace them.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The show, which primarily focused on the couple's marriage and the recording of Simpson's third studio album, premiered on August 19, 2003.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The show instantly became a pop culture phenomenon, with Simpson's perceived "dumb blonde" antics on the show helping to make the couple a household name.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The series was a ratings success for MTV, and aired for three seasons until 2005.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson's third studio album, In This Skin (2003), was released the day that Newlyweds: Nick and Jessica premiered, with the show serving as a promotional tool for the record.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: In This Skin debuted at number ten on the Billboard 200, selling 64,000 copies in its first week of release.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The album's opening numbers served as the lowest of Simpson's career at the time.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: In This Skin quickly declined the chart, and by January 2004 had sold just over 565,000 copies in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson released "With You" (2003) as the second single from the album in October.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The single became a hit, reaching the top twenty of the Billboard Hot 100 and topping the Mainstream Top 40 chart based on radio airplay.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson appeared in the halftime show of the Super Bowl XXXVIII.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: She recorded new material for a re-release of In This Skin, which was released in March 2004.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The re-release dramatically aided in album sales; In This Skin went on to sell three million copies in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Both "Take My Breath Away" (2004) and "Angels" (2004) were released as singles from the re-release.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson and Lachey starred in the ABC special The Nick and Jessica Variety Hour in April, which featured guest appearances by celebrities such as Jewel and Mr. T, among others.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: That same month, she launched her Jessica Simpson Desserts by Jessica Simpson cosmetics line along with Randi Shinder; all of the products in the line were edible.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson embarked on her Reality Tour (2004) throughout North America beginning in June; the tour was a financial success, and ended in October.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: During this time, Simpson and her husband began making guest appearances on The Ashlee Simpson Show, chronicling the start of Jessica's sister's music career.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson's fourth studio album, a collection of Christmas themed songs titled ReJoyce: The Christmas Album (2004), was released on November 23.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The album reached a peak of number fourteen on the Billboard 200, and was certified gold by the RIAA for sales exceeding 500,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Also in 2004, Simpson filmed a sitcom pilot for ABC, which the network did not pick-up.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: In February 2005, Simpson and Shinder launched the Dessert Treats edible cosmetics line, similar to their prior line but targeted towards a younger audience.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Both lines were canceled following a string of lawsuits.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson performed "The Star-Spangled Banner" at the Indy 500 in 2005.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson launched The Jessica Simpson Collection in 2005, initially partnering with Tarrant Apparel Group to release the Princy and JS by Jessica Simpson clothing lines.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The company has continued to grow throughout the years, and in 2014 was reported to earn $1 billion in annual sales.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson made her film debut as Daisy Duke in the film adaption of The Dukes of Hazzard (2005).
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: While the film was met with generally negative reviews from film critics, it went on to gross over $111 million worldwide.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson recorded the song "These Boots Are Made For Walkin'" (2005) to promote the film; it both samples and shares the title of a Nancy Sinatra song.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The song entered the top twenty of the Billboard Hot 100, becoming one Simpson's most successful singles to date.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The music video, which featured Simpson in character as Daisy Duke, was controversial for featuring Simpson in "revealing" outfits and washing the General Lee car in her bikini.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: The controversy resulted in the music video being banned in some countries.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: In November 2005, Simpson and Lachey announced they were separating.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Simpson filed for divorce in December 2005, citing "irreconcilable differences."
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: Their divorce was publicized worldwide and was finalized on June 30, 2006.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2005: Marriage to Nick Lachey and heightened success ===

sentences: She reportedly had to pay Lachey $12 million in their divorce as she had not signed a pre-nuptial agreement before they wed. In a 2015 interview, Simpson called her marriage to Lachey her "biggest financial mistake".

sentences: Simpson's attempt to transition into country music was met with a negative reaction.
section: == Life and career == | === 2006–2009: A Public Affair, movies and Do You Know ===

sentences: Most notably, Simpson was booed by the crowd following a performance at the Country Thunder Festival in Wisconsin.
section: == Life and career == | === 2006–2009: A Public Affair, movies and Do You Know ===

sentences: Simpson was also referenced in Eminem's 2009 song, "We Made You", and portrayed by Trisha Paytas.

sentences: === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson's VH1 documentary series, The Price of Beauty, began airing in March 2010.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The series followed Simpson around the world, introducing viewers to the different perceptions of beauty in different cultures.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The premiere episode attracted one million viewers, but Simpson revealed that the series would return in 2011 with a format change; these plans never came to fruition.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson initially had plans to record her seventh studio album as her final release through Epic Records, though ultimately released the compilation album Playlist: The Very Best of Jessica Simpson (2010).
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The album was released with no promotion and had little success.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: She later signed a new recording contract with eleveneleven and Primary Wave Music and began working on her Christmas themed seventh studio album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Happy Christmas (2010) was released on November 22; it briefly appeared on the lower half of the Billboard 200 before falling off the chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson began dating retired NFL tight end Eric Johnson in May 2010; the couple announced their engagement in November 2010.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson appeared alongside Nicole Richie as a mentor on the NBC reality television series Fashion Star.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The series revolved around a group of designers who competed each week to create clothing; each week, one contestant was eliminated.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The series aired the second season in 2013, though was canceled afterward.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Following months of speculation, Simpson confirmed on Halloween of 2011 that she was pregnant with her first child.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Weight Watchers in 2012, vowing to use their diet plan to shed the weight gained during her pregnancy.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson filmed television commercials for the company, with the first airing in September 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson gave birth to a daughter, Maxwell Drew Johnson, on May 1, 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson launched a maternity clothing line in 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: She later released a perfume, Vintage Bloom, which was inspired by motherhood.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson confirmed in December 2012 that she was expecting a second child with Johnson.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Following the announcement, Weight Watchers announced that she would discontinue following the company's diet plan during her pregnancy.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson gave birth to her son, Ace Knute Johnson, on June 30, 2013.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: She launched a bedroom decor line including bedding and draperies offered in a romantic bohemian style, with floral patterns.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In August 2014, a signature fragrance was added.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson and Johnson married in July 2014 in Montecito, California.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In 2013, it was announced that Simpson was in talks with NBC to star in a semi-autobiographical comedy series, but the project never materialized.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson confirmed in 2015 that she would begin working on her album, as her contract with Primary Wave had officially ended.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson is working with Linda Perry on the project, which she revealed in 2016.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In August 2015, Simpson was a host on the HSN channel while promoting her products.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The sales were a success.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Simpson launched her Warm Up brand of workout clothing, available at retailers in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: The brand was expanded in August 2016 to include trainers, with Simpson commenting that the line would become more of a focus for her in the future.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In September 2018, Simpson announced she was pregnant with her third child, a daughter.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: She gave birth to their daughter, Birdie Mae Johnson, on March 19, 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: On February 2, 2020, Simpson released her memoir Open Book, which topped The New York Times Best Seller list.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In the book, she discussed topics such as her marriage to Nick Lachey, her relationship with musician John Mayer, sexual abuse she experienced during her childhood, dependence on alcohol and prescription drugs, and the pressure she felt to lose weight, which caused her body image issues.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: Six new songs were released as part of the book, marking her first release in music since Happy Christmas in 2010.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In December 2020, Simpson signed a multi-media rights deal with Amazon, and released an essay on motherhood titled Take the Lead the following April.
section: == Life and career == | === 2010–present: Motherhood, second marriage, and focus on business ventures ===

sentences: In November 2021, Simpson released a cover of English rock band Nothing but Thieves' song, "Particles", thus marking her first single release since "My Only Wish" in 2010.

== Musical style ==

sentences: Musical style ==
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Simpson has listed Mariah Carey, Aretha Franklin, Sade, and Whitney Houston as influences on her music.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: She attempted to launch her career as a Christian music singer, and at one point completed a self-titled album of Christian music.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: When she signed with Columbia Records in 1998, she began working on an album of pop music.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Simpson has recorded songs with Christian themes in later years, including "Pray Out Loud" (2008).
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: The music found on her debut album primarily consisted of pop ballads, with the intention of showcasing Simpson's vocals.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: AllMusic's Stephen Thomas Erlewine opined that the album "position[ed] her as the teen Celine Dion".
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Most notably, it featured the power ballad "I Wanna Love You Forever" (1999).
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: The music found on her debut drew comparisons to Mariah Carey.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: With the release of Irresistible (2001), Simpson recorded more upbeat songs, likening herself to artists such as Britney Spears.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Songs such as "Irresistible" and "A Little Bit" had more provocative lyrics in comparison to her previous release, with Simpson citing the age difference between the recording of the two albums as the main reason.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: During the Total Request Live Tour (2001) and her DreamChaser Tour (2001), Simpson incorporated more choreography and backup dancers into her live performances.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Simpson initially began working on her third studio album in 2002, which was set to primarily be produced by rapper Missy Elliott.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: The record later took on a new direction, which her then-husband Nick Lachey described as "organic" in comparison to her prior two albums.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Simpson also began co-writing her own songs for the record, something she had been nervous to do in the past.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: The result was In This Skin (2003), a record that AllMusic said "stay[ed] within the contemporary dance-pop realm while inching toward the middle-of-the-road diva that she's always yearned to be."
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Simpson worked with elements of country music with the release of "These Boots Are Made For Walkin'" (2005), recorded for Simpson's feature film debut The Dukes of Hazzard (2005).
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: She continued to experiment with the genre on the song "Push Your Tush" (2006).
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Numerous songs on her fifth studio album feature elements of dance and disco music, most notably "A Public Affair" and her cover of "You Spin Me Round (Like a Record)".
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Inspired by artists such as Faith Hill, Shania Twain and Martina McBride, Simpson recorded a country music album titled Do
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: You Know (2008).
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Throughout her career, Simpson has delved into other genres as well, releasing two Christmas-themed albums in 2004 and 2010.
section: == Musical style ==
== Public image ==

sentences: Public image
section: == Public image ==
== Public image ==

sentences: Simpson came to prominence as a teen idol in the late 1990s and was described as Columbia Records's "blond response to Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera", who had recently achieved success with their respective debut albums.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Her debut album, Sweet Kisses (1999) mostly explores themes such as love, and Simpson announced that she would remain abstinent until marriage.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: She went through a "carefully orchestrated sexy makeover" while promoting her second album, Irresistible (2001).
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson later described Columbia's record executive Tommy Mottola as abusive, as he was trying to control her image and told her to "lose fifteen pounds" after she signed her contract in 1997.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Upon Simpson's rise to stardom with the success of Newlyweds: Nick and Jessica in 2003, she was seen as a "ditzy blonde" based on her antics and comments on the show.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: The Washington Post's Emily Yahr called her "one of our first reality TV stars, before anyone could absorb the psychological damage it could cause."
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson recalled her time in the show in her 2020 memoir Open Book, saying: "Nowadays, I see so many people performing their identities on social media, but I feel like I was a guinea pig for that.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: How was I supposed to live a real, healthy life filtered through the lens of a reality show?
section: == Public image ==

sentences: If my personal life was my work, and my work required me to play a certain role, who even was I anymore?"She is described as a sex symbol by the media.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson's portrayal of Daisy Duke furthered her sex symbol image, and she portrayed the character in her "These Boots Are Made For Walkin" music video, which presents "footage of Simpson writhing suggestively against a suds-soaked motor vehicle".
section: == Public image ==

sentences: The scene was parodied in Pink's "Stupid Girls" music video.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson also appeared as Daisy Duke in several television commercials for Pizza Hut airing during the Super Bowl in 2006 and 2007.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson claimed that the "[Daisy Duke] role created a "gold standard" that she would be judged by in the years that followed", and she was subject of intense media scrutiny following her weight gain in 2009.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson is a registered Republican.
section: == Public image ==

sentences: She endorsed George W. Bush during his presidential campaign in 2004, though she canceled an appearance at a 2006 Republican fundraiser as she felt it was not "appropriate".
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Though a Republican, Simpson has praised former First Lady Michelle Obama during her husband's time in office, stating, "She's such an incredible woman, and she's with such a powerful man...
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Everything she does she exudes confidence."
section: == Public image ==

sentences: Simpson is Soles4Souls's Ambassador where she participated in autographing shoes to donate the money from communities across the United States.
